content.description: This is rarely done, but it is an interesting route. The bottom appears runout, but it is not too bad. After you turn the corner onto the face, the challenges begin, thin, techy slab climbing. It is a little heady but is generally safe. The bolts are old but appear solid. This has multiple cruxes with small holds and tricky sequences. The finishing crack is loose, easy, and a little scary. I got a #2 in, but the rock is poor, and I wouldn't have wanted to fall on it. Small cams may fit as well.
content.protection: About 9 draws, a few finger-sized pieces, and a #2 for the top. The anchor needs new webbing, I may get around to swapping it out soon.
content.location:
It is left of

Bush & Dirt Crack aka Pseudo-Cenotaph aka I Need a Shower

and shares a start with

For Better of For Worse

. This then breaks right at the second bolt.

content.description:
This is a pretty fun route that not many climb, since the start doesn't have much gear.  Most traverse in from the right to keep the grade at 5.9.  It is also possible to do a direct start that goes at 5.10+.  Gain a left-facing crack that forms several small roofs and follow it to the top.

THERE IS A FIXED STATIC LINE IN THIS AREA THAT IS USED BY THE LOCAL SAR AND CLIMBING COMMUNITY. PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE IT! IT IS EASILY FLICKED OUT OF THE WAY WHEN CLIMBING. THANKS.
content.protection: Standard East A rack & a couple drilled pins?
content.location:
The route starts on the face left of

Jabba the Hutt Levitates

.

content.description:
This is actually a third pitch to

I Need A Shower

or a second pitch for

In Mesopotamia

.  Climb the obvious, wide crack with many face holds leading up and right.
content.protection: Standard East A rack + big gear.
content.location:
Start atop the second pitch of

I Need A Shower

.

content.description:
After pulling the first crux of

The Love Movement

, rest up at the jug until you are ready to embark on an incredibly technical and unforgiving series of crimps involving matching a ridiculous, 2 finger crimp and navigating multiple sloping edges up a gentle bulge.
content.protection: Bolts and Mussy hooks at the anchors.
content.location:
Climb

The Love Movement

to the permanent draw, then exit going straight up and right.

content.description: This is a great route on soft looking but highly featured sandstone - it is the sandstone version of tufa climbing. The cruxes are at the first bolt and another is at the fun mantle midway.
content.protection:
Bolts and a fixed stopper at the roof - eleven clips. There are fixed biners at the anchor.

Per

David Kozak

: the FA was done with two bolts and one fixed wire in the upper dihedral.
content.location:
It is located 20 feet right of

I Need a Shower

.

content.description:
This shares a start with "

Dune

", 10 feet right of

I Need a Shower

.  It is the left route at the 3rd bolt. The crux is near the top - thin pockets and pinches. Fun.
content.protection:
Bolts. It shares an anchor with "

Dune

" to the right.

content.description:
Climb the obvious wide crack past a wedged block and finish at a bolted anchor near a tree. Continue up

Steve Likes Offwidth

for more fun.
content.location:
This is right of

I Need a Shower

.

content.description:
This is a new 12 bolt sport route for the Jabba zone. Established during the non-winter of 2017-2018, this one took a lot of cleaning, but I think it shaped up nicely.

A shoulder length sling on the third bolt will greatly reduce your rope.

It seems like this will be one of those routes that gets change as the years go by and key holds break off.

We are currently working on a direct finish that will likely be a little more difficult. The Love Movement traverses left at the tenth bolt (with fixed draw).

UPDATE: Nolan Robertson got that done, and named it Scantron, rating it 5.13a

For those looking for an extra pump, The Love Movement can be combined with the second pitch of

I Need a Shower

for a "Love Shower".

The name The Love Movement is after A Tribe Called Quest album.
content.location:
This climb is right of

I Need A Shower

.

content.description:
The route starts at an easy face to the right of the

Watch Crystal

.  Climb the face/cracks up towards a large wedged flake (Jabba). Mantle the flake and follow the crack in the left-facing corner. At the top of the crack, move left to the anchor.
content.location: On the left side of the Jabba Buttress area, look for the large, sketchy-looking flake and corner crack.

content.description:
Climb an initial blocky section with a tree growing out of it.  Then up a nice, but short finger crack.  Towards the top the angle eases and the crack widens to hands.  Build an anchor (#0.75 - #2 Camalots).

Rappel from anchor for

I Need a Shower

or continue up

Steve Likes Offwidth

.
content.location:
This is one route right of

I Need a Shower

.

content.description:
Boulder up the blunt arete aiming for a U-shaped hold, clip a bolt, and mantle onto the sloping ledge. Clip three more bolts where the arete steepens. After the forth bolt, make a committing move straight up and stay on the arete (the further from the last bolt the easier it gets).

The third bolt looks worse than it actually is. There are amazing jugs that make the clip a lot easier than you think it will be.
content.location:
This is left of

Three Open Books

by 10 feet.

content.description: This is an easy route that is good for beginners.  It climbs a slabby face with cracks and a bolt.
content.location:
The start is the same as that of

Jabba the Hut Levitates

.

content.description:
This route shares the first 3 bolts and anchor with

Odale'!

to the left.  It is a jug haul to a thin crux above a roof.
content.location:
This is 10 feet to the right of

I Need A Shower

.

content.description: This has a hard start off the ground (11+) with very little feet! You might want to stick clip the first bolt. Clip first two bolts of existing 5.12 route that goes hard right after 2nd bolt, then go straight up and enjoy jugs once you get above your second bolt till you get to the 4th bolt. From here, it gets harder through the roof moves. I recently moved the upper lead bolt down and added another bolt above the previous last bolt. This protects the crux much better to the anchors. The crux is getting onto the bulge to your left and the final clipping hold of the anchors. The rock is super solid.
content.location:
This route starts on an existing 5.12 just to the left of "

I Need A Shower

". Stick with the bolt line that goes straight up from the second bolt.

climbs.name: Bush & Dirt Crack aka Pseudo-Cenotaph aka I Need a Shower

content.description:
P1. Climb the right-facing corner that starts with large huecos and goes past a small roof then continues to follow a finger crack in the corner to a bolted anchor at a ledge (5.7).

P2. Traverse a little right on the ledge and climb a short flake handcrack (5.7+). Finish at bolts.

Descent: from the top of P2, one single 60m rope will get you down. Or, continue on

Steve Likes Offwidth

.
content.location:
Continue past

Jabba the Hutt Levitates

to a right-facing corner with a few bolted lines on the face to the right. This is the start of the route.

content.description:
Breaking Boundary is an extension to the fantastic

Breaking Ben

. It entails two technical boulder problems separated from the

Breaking Ben

crux by an insecure, no-hands stance. While the crux finish may at first seem contrived, the rock is excellent, and the exposure unbelievable. The boundary is the imaginary line that separates the impeccable headwall from the roof above. I recommend not bailing to the chossy roof holds, but if you do, be prepared to clean them yourself and to earn fewer points for the send.
content.protection:
12 bolts + an anchor (7 bolts of

Breaking Ben

lead to 5 additional bolts for Breaking Boundary) +/- optional gear for the initial slab leading to

Breaking Ben

.
content.location:
Start by climbing most of

Breaking Ben

. At the 7th of

Breaking Ben’s

eight bolts, mantel up to take on the steep prow above. Trend slightly right from the initial stance to follow four bolts through the steep prow. Finally, commit to the line of strength traversing left across the headwall to top out the left arête. Clip the anchors at your right hip or knee once you have gained the jugs around the corner.

content.description:
Climb

Face To Nowhere

to 8 bolts leading up the dramatic arete!

This is the ultimate testpiece at East Animas, demanding an incredible amount of focus, technique, crimp strength, sloper strength, unwavering endurance, and razor precision.

Originally envisioned by Ben Griffin, he suggested I get on it, and I became maniacally obsessed with the single best pitch of climbing I have ever been on. After multiple seasons of efforts, I failed to send after several very good attempts and many one hangs. I moved to the Front Range for about a year after visiting Durango four times over the course of the year coming back to attempt to free this route. Other people in the climbing community believed it to be too height-dependent and modified the initial stopper/impossible crux with glued holds eliminating the original sequence that I used. After moving back to Durango, I put in five more days of effort to send the line in its current state, still one of the best sport climbing pitches I have ever done. I chose the name Doppleganger, because the original climb was slightly different; however, it is strikingly similar.
content.protection:
Climbing

Face To Nowhere

, you can use a couple of small cams. As for the sport section, it is usually fixed with permadraws of some kind.
content.location:
Climb

Face To Nowhere

, then bust up and left climbing up the incredible arete.

content.description: This route has nice rock and nice movement.  It is a really good route that deserves more attention.
content.protection: Bolts. One could bring a hand-sized cam for the top.
content.location:
Look for the line of bolts on the varnished rock just left of Jabba. Finish on the last few moves of

Jabba the Hutt Levitates

.  Rap from the anchor.

content.description: Don't let the length of this little hussy mislead you, it packs a punch (much like my ...). Very technical and bouldery climbing leads to a baller ender crux comprised of shit crimps and big moves!! If you wanna be a sissy (like me), you can TR before trying to lead it by lowering in from the long .10 to the left.
content.location: This is the shorty just right of the long .10. This is the furthest right line on Jabba Buttress.

content.description:
Bathing Beauty is a bolted route that starts right at the ledge of the 1st anchor of "

I Need A Shower

". It is well-protected and has a two bolt anchor at the top with newly added chains.
content.location:
It starts right at the ledge of the 1st anchor of "

I Need A Shower

".
